let firstName = {1:SHORTANSWER_C:~=document.forms["myForm"].firstName.value~=document.forms['myForm'].firstName.value~%50%document.forms["myForm"].firstName~%50%document.forms['myForm'].firstName};

<form id="order">
  <output name="lastName" />
</form>

{1:SHORTANSWER_C:~=document.forms["order"].lastName.value~=document.forms['order'].lastName.value~%50%document.forms["order"].lastName~%50%document.forms['order'].lastName} = lastName;
Recall that an HTML form is a section of a document consisting of block elements that contain controls and labels on those controls. Which of the following form elements represent correct forms?

answer.text:
<form>
  <div>
    <label for="isbn">ISBN: </label><input id="isbn" name="isbn" />
    <label for="title">title: </label><input id="title" name="title" />
  </div>
</form>

feedback.text: Missing id attributes in the input elements (needed as targets of the for references).
Missing id attributes in the input elements and corresponding for attributes in the label elements, needed for connecting the label with the control.
Labels and controls are not wrapped by block-level elements.

name.text: How to prevent a form submission

questiontext.text: How can a form submission be prevented (e.g. in the case of a non-valid user input)?

answer.text: By calling the preventDefault DOM operation in the event handler function for the activation of the submit button.
By calling the resetForm DOM operation in the event handler function for the activation of the submit button.
By keeping the focus in the input filed that contains the invalid value.
The form submission cannot be prevented.

questiontext.text:
In some cases the same request message can be expressed either with GET or with POST.

Consider the following POST request message:

POST /index.php HTTP/1.1
Host: www.example.org

name=Gerd+Wagner&OK=true

Complete the following GET request message such that it expresses the same request message:

GET {1:SHORTANSWER_C:~=/index.php?name=Gerd+Wagner&OK=true} HTTP/1.1
Host: www.example.org
Which of the following are correct GET request messages?

feedback.text: Although the version of HTTP that is in common use today is 1.1, the older version 1.0 is still being used.
Any HTTP GET request message must include the header field Host.
The request line must include the HTTP version.

questiontext.text:
Consider the following HTML form:

<form action="http://example.org/test.php" method="get">
 <p><label><input type="checkbox" name="OOP" id="OOP01" value="Java" /> I like Java</label></p>
 <p><label><input type="checkbox" name="OOP" id="OOP02" value="C++" /> I like C++</label></p>
 <p><button type="submit">Submit</button></p>
</form>

Which of the following represent correct HTTP GET request URLs created when the form is submitted?
Which HTTP messages have an empty body?

answer.text: A GET response message with a status code of 200.

feedback.text: A GET response message with a status code of 200 (OK) delivers the requested information (e.g., a HTML document) in its message body.
A POST request message needs a message body for transporting any information such as (form submission) parameter values or a message payload.
A GET request message may transmit query parameter values encoded as part of the path, but it does not use a message body.
A POST response message transmits the confirmation or error message in its message body.

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements are correct?

A proxy can hide the user's identity by acting on behalf of the user.
A proxy can be used for filtering HTTP request messages.
A proxy can resolve DNS request messages.
A proxy can convert human-readable HTTP messages into encrypted HTTPS messages.

questiontext.text:
Consider the following JavaScript code fragment:

function BubblingAndCapturing() {
  document.body.addEventListener("click", listener_body, false);
  document.getElementById("para").addEventListener("click", listener_p, true);
  document.getElementById("div").addEventListener("click", listener_div, false);
  document.getElementById("span").addEventListener("click", listener_span, true);
}

function listener_body() { alert("Alert: You clicked on body!"); }
function listener_p() { alert("Alert: You clicked on paragraph!"); }
function listener_div() { alert("Alert: You clicked on div!"); }
function listener_span() { alert("Alert: You clicked on span!");}

window.addEventListener("load", BubblingAndCapturing);

<body>
  <div id="div">

Explain the two language elements of MySQL/MariaDB-SQL that can be used for defining enumeration-valued columns in a CREATE TABLE statement.

generalfeedback.text: MySQL provides two special column types for enumeration attributes: ENUM and SET. ENUM is used for single-valued enumeration attributes while SET allows multivalued enumeration attributes.

questiontext.text:
Complete the code of the following SQL trigger, which allows to check if the year value is greater or equal with 1800 and lower or equal with next year. Use the appropriate SQL syntax.

CREATE TRIGGER checkYear
  BEFORE INSERT ON history
  FOR EACH ROW
BEGIN
  IF {1:SHORTANSWER_C:%100%NEW.year < 1800 OR NEW.year > (YEAR( CURDATE()) + 1)} THEN 
    SIGNAL SQLSTATE '22003' 
    SET MESSAGE_TEXT = 'year must be in the range [1800, nextYear]';
  END IF;
END;

Complete the following program for starting an HTTP server with Node.js.

var http = require("http");
function startHttpServer() {
  function onRequest( request, response) {
    console.log("Request received.");
    response.writeHead( 200, 
        {"Content-Type": "text/plain"});
    response.write("Hello World");
    response.end();
  }
  http.createServer({1:SHORTANSWER_C:~=onRequest}).listen(8888);
  console.log("Server has started.");
}

Which of the getter method will be executed when the user submits the form?

Consider the following code fragment:

@Path("/users/{username}/friends")
@Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)
public class FriendsService {
  @GET public List list(
      @PathParam("username") String username,
      @QueryParam("key") String key) {
    String password = getPassword( username, key);
    Twitter twitter = new Twitter( username, password);
    List<Twitter.User> users = new LinkedList();
    for (Twitter.User twitterUser : twitter.getFriends()) {
      users.add( new User( twitterUser.getName(), twitterUser.getStatus().getText()));
    }
    return users;  // the list of friends
  }
}

Assumming that the base URL of my REST service is http://www.twitteria.org/, the user name is "crock" and the key is "Pgk3MK42", what is the HTTP GET request URL such that the above code will return the list of Twitter friends?

Consider a digital printing web service implemented as a REST web service with Zend Framework 2. The service provides the possibility to create and maintain a catalog of your digital pictures.

A request to delete one of your pictures with name MyDog.jpg would be expressed as the HTTP message  DELETE http://www.digital-photo.com/catalog/MyDog.jpg

Which of the following statements are correct:

answer.text: It is required to have at least one route definition in the configuration file that contains the following segment [/:controller][/:id] in order to be able to perform the DELETE operation.
There must be a controller class with name CatalogController that extends AbstractRestfulController and implements the method delete($id) taking care of the picture deletion operation.
There must be a controller class with name CatalogRestfulController that implements the method deletePicture( $id, $pictureData) taking  care of the picture deletion operation.
No controller class is required because DELETE operations are implemented and invoked automatically by the Zend Framework 2.

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements are true with respect to ZF2's support of REST web services?

answer.text: Using ZF2 for creating REST web services frees the programmer from taking care of  many HTTP programming details and allows her to focus on the service functionality.

ZF2 allows to add functionality to your web service by using built-in packages, such as database management and security handling, and also allows creating a client for the web service using forms, form validators, progress bars, etc.
ZF2 provides widgets that allow you building a skeleton REST web service with a few mouse clicks.
In the area of REST web services, the main feature of ZF2 is to help creating web service clients in a fast and easy manner.

questiontext.text:
Fill in the right name of the SOAP body child element, according to the WSDL on the left.

WSDL service descriptionCorresponding SOAP message for invoking the operation o1
...
<types>
  <xs:schema>
    <xs:element name="MT1">
      <xs:complexType>
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element name="c1" type="xs:int"/>
          <xs:element name="c2" type="xs:string"/>
        <xs:/sequence>
      <xs:/complexType>
    <xs:/element>
  <xs:/schema>
</types>
<message name="im1">
  <part name="parameters" element="MT1"/>
</message>
...
<portType name="PT">
  <operation name="o1">
    <input message="im1"/>
    <output message="om1"/>
  </operation>
</portType>
<binding ...>
  <soap:binding style="document" ... /> 
  ...
</binding>
...

<soap:envelope>
  <soap:body>
    <{1:SHORTANSWER:=MT1}>
      <c1>123</c1>
      <c2>ABC</c2>
    </...>
  </soap:body>
</soap:envelope>

generalfeedback.text: If the binding style is "document", then the name of the SOAP body child element of the input message is the name of the message type element associated with the WSDL message part of the input message of the operation to be invoked.

questiontext.text: Which of the following sentences about associations are correct?

answer.text: Associations are relationship types with two or more object types participating in them.
An association between object types classifies relationships between objects of those types.
Associations are relationships between two or more participating objects.

feedback.text: Associations are relationships between object types, and not between objects. They classify relationships between objects.

answer.text: Binary associations must have a direction from one class to the other class.

feedback.text: Associations can be uni-directional, bi-directional or undirected.

questiontext.text: In which of the following association-free models is the unidirectional association correctly represented?

Consider the information design model with two unidirectional associations between the classes Committee and ClubMember.

Which of the following OO class models represent this model correctly?
Which of the following statements about a single-valued reference property r with range class R and how it should be represented in a web user interface by a suitable form control are correct?

answer.text: It can always be represented by a single-selection list (a select element).
If the cardinality of R is not greater than 7, it can be represented by a radio button group.
If the cardinality of R is not greater than 7, it can be represented by a checkbox group.
A good choice for representing it is using an input element with type="text".

feedback.text: This is not a good choice because it does not prevent the user from entering invalid ID references.

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements about a multi-valued reference property p and how it should be represented in a web user interface by a suitable form control are correct?

answer.text: It can be represented by a muliple-select control if there are not too many different options to choose from (otherwise, if there are too many different options, using a muliple-select control is not acceptable from a usability point of view).
If the cardinality of p's range is not greater than 7, it can be represented by a check button group.
If the cardinality of p's range is not greater than 7, it can be represented by a radio button group.
It can always be represented by a muliple-select control because a single-select control is visually too scattered if there are many options.

questiontext.text: A uni-directional binary association is functional if and only if:

answer.text: Each object of the source class is linked to at most one object of the target class.
Each object of the source class is linked to exactly one object of the target class.
Each object of the source class is linked to at least one object of the target class.
Each object of the target class is linked to at most one object of the source class.

feedback.text: In this case, the uni-directional binary association is inverse functional.

questiontext.text: What does it mean to say that an association is "many-to-many"? It is ...
Which of the following terms can be used for expressing that an association is neither functional nor inverse functional?
Assume that we have an object type B with a standard identifier property id and an object type A with a reference property bIdRef with range B. Which of the following statements are correct?

answer.text: A new object of type A with bIdRef="17" can only be created when an object of type B with id="17" has been created before.

It's a safe and user-friendly approach to prevent the user, when creating a new object of type A, from entering a value for bIdRef manually, but require her to select a value from a list of all objects of type B.

If the user, when creating a new object of type A, has to select a value for bIdRef from a list of all objects of type B, then there is no need to check the referential integrity for bIdRef in the user interface.
A new object of type B with id="17" can only be created when an object of type A with bIdRef="17" has been created before.

questiontext.text: Assume that we have an object type B with a standard identifier attribute id and an object type A with an ID reference attribute b_id referencing B::id. Further, assume that there is an object b of type B with b.id = 11 and an object a of type A referencing b with a.b_id = 11. Which of the following statements are correct?

answer.text: The object b can be destroyed when a has been destroyed before.
The object b can be destroyed when the ID reference in object a is unassigned (by setting  a.b_id to undefined in JS, or to null in Java) and there is no other object that references b.
The object b can be destroyed when the ID reference in object a is reset to another object of type B, e.g. by setting  a.bIdRef = 7 and there is no other object that references b.
The object a can only be destroyed when b has been destroyed before.

questiontext.text: What does it mean to say that an association is "one-to-one"? It must be ...
Which of the following terms can be used for expressing that an association is both functional and inverse functional?
A referential integrity constraint for a reference property C::p with range class D has to be checked whenever

answer.text: A new object of type C is created.
The value of p is changed for some object of type C.
An object of type D is destroyed.
A new object of type D is created.
An object of type C is destroyed.

questiontext.text: We model the reference property A::refB shown in the first diagram as a unidirectional association in the second diagram. Which of the following statements about the (anonymous) association end at A are correct and help to find its multiplicity?

answer.text: Its minimum cardinality is 1 if each B is the refB of at least one A.
Its maximum cardinality is 1 if each B is the refB of at most one A.
Its minimum cardinality is 0 if each B is the refB of at least one A.
Its maximum cardinality is 1 if each A has at most one B as refB.

questiontext.text: Define the concept of bidirectional associations. A bidirectional association between the classes A and B is ...

answer.text: Represented by two mutually inverse reference properties (like A::b and B::a).
Represented as a pair of multi-valued reference properties (like A::b and B::a).
Represented as a pair of functional reference properties (like A::b and B::a).
A many-to-many association between A and B that can be navigated in both directions.

questiontext.text:
Consider the information design model with a bidirectional association between the classes Aa and Bb.

Which of the following association-free models are correct representations of this model?

feedback.text: An association is represented in a UML class diagram with object reference properties, and not with ID reference properties.
The reference property Aa::r1 must have the same multiplicity as the association end r1.

questiontext.text: Representing an association with a pair of mutually inverse reference properties instead of only one reference property implies

answer.text: more efficient data storage requiring less memory

questiontext.text:
Recall that, given two classes A and B, the notation A::b : B means that b is a reference property defined in A (its domain) with range B.

A bidirectional association Committee-isChairedBy-ClubMember between the classes Committee and ClubMember is equivalent to ....

answer.text: A pair of reference properties Committee::chair : ClubMember and ClubMember::chairedCommittee : Committee such that chair is the inverse of chairedCommittee.
A pair of reference properties Committee::chair : ClubMember and ClubMember::chairedCommittee : Committee such that chairedCommittee is the inverse of chair.

A pair of reference properties Committee::chair : ClubMember and ClubMember::chairedCommittee : Committee such that chair is the inverse of chairedCommittee and chairedCommittee is the inverse of chair.

feedback.text: If chair is the inverse of chairedCommittee, then chairedCommittee is the inverse of chair.

answer.text: A pair of reference properties Committee::chair : ClubMember and ClubMember::chairedCommittee : Committee.

feedback.text: Without being the inverse of each other, such a pair does not correspond to a bidirectional association.

answer.text: A pair of reference properties Committee::chair : ClubMember and ClubMember::chairedCommittee : Committee such that both chair and chairedCommittee are many-valued.

feedback.text: Without being the inverse of each other, such a pair does not correspond to a bidirectional association.

questiontext.text:
Given two classes A and B, the notation A::b: B means that b is a reference property defined in A with range B.

A bidirectional association between the classes A and B is equivalent to ....

answer.text: A pair of reference properties A::b: B and B::a: A such that b is the inverse of a.

feedback.text: Notice that if A::b is the inverse of B::a, this implies that B::a is also the inverse of A::b.

answer.text: A pair of reference properties A::b: B and B::a: A such that both b and a are many-valued.
A pair of string-valued ID reference properties A::bIdRef: String and B::aIdRef: String.

feedback.text: Without being the inverse of each other, such a pair does not correspond to a bidirectional association.

answer.text: A pair of internal reference properties A::b: B and B::a: A.

feedback.text: Without being the inverse of each other, such a pair does not correspond to a bidirectional association.

questiontext.text: Which of the following features are new in Java/JPA/JSF web apps compared to NodeJS/Geddy web apps?

answer.text: support for different lifetimes of objects (e.g. an object may be destroyed when the user request has been processed or it may stay alive for the entire user session)
support for multiple SQL DBMS with object-to-relation mappings (converting objects to rows and vice versa)
support for multiple HTML template technologies in the view layer

Which of the following classes are JavaBean classes?

  public void setName( String n) {this.name = n;}
}

  private String name;
  public String getName() {return this.name;}
  public void setName( String n) {this.name = n;}
}

feedback.text: A bean class doesn't need a constructor, since a parameter-free default constructor will be created automatically.

answer.text:
public class Person {
  private String name;
  public Person( String n) {this.setName(n);}
  public String getName() {return this.name;}
  public void setName( String n) {this.name = n;}
}

feedback.text: Whenever a bean class has a constructor, it also needs to have a parameter-free default constructor.

answer.text:
public class Person {
  private String name;
  public Person() {}
  public Person( String n) {this.setName(n);}
  public void setName( String n) {this.name = n;}
}

feedback.text: A getter is missing. Any bean class needs getters and setters.

answer.text:
public class Person {
  String name;
  public Person() {}
  public Person( String n) {this.setName(n);}
  public String getName() {return this.name;}
  public void setName( String n) {this.name = n;}
}

feedback.text: In bean class, all attributes must be private.

questiontext.text: A web app for managing data about students is based on a model class Student. It has to display a list of all student IDs in the form of a table. It uses a managed bean  studentsCtrl that is an instance of a controller class StudentController with a getStudents() method. Select the correct JSF facelet code which creates the required table.

feedback.text: The value of the value attribute for the h:dataTable element must be value="#{studentsCtrl.students}".
We can't invoke getters for reading the ID attribute, instead we have to use the attribute name, which is mapped to a corresponding getter.
The #{id} expression lacks an object context, which is provided by the student variable.

name.text: JSF: create select list and populate with data

questiontext.text: The UI of a students management Web Application allows to select a student record to be updated by name. A StudentController bean studentCtrl was created. Select the correct JSF facelet code which creates and populates the single selection HTML list with student names and binds the selected value to the id property of the  student model object.

feedback.text: The student instance is missing in for the itemValue and itemLabel attrubutes of the f:selectItems element.
Missing value="#{student.id}" for the h:selectOneMenu element

Incorrect because the value attribute for the h:selectOneMenu element has as value the managed bean instance (i.e. student), while it must point to the id property of this instance (i.e. value="#{student.id}".

questiontext.text:
Consider the folllowing JPA entity class definition code fragment:

@Id @NotNull( message="A name is required!")
private String name;

@Column( nullable=false)
@NotNull( message="An address is required!")
private String address;

Which of the annotations used expresses the same constraint as which other one? Why is this constraint expressed twice?

graderinfo.text:
1. Both @Id and @NotNull define a mandatory value constraint for the same property.
  2. Both @Column( nullable=false) and @NotNull define a mandatory value constraint for the same property.
These mandatory value constraints are defined twice because one definition (JPA) is for the database, and the other one (Bean Validation) is for the Java runtime.

questiontext.text: Explain how we can check the uniqueness of a value for the standard identifier attribute of a Java object instantiating an entity class, when using Java EE.

    Object value) throws Exception {

Which of the following are valid type casts in Java?

A Person model class contains a birthDate attribute, which is to be validated with a custom annotation implementing the constraint that the difference between the current date (when a new record is created) and the birthDate value must not be greater than 100 years.

Select the code fragment that correctly defines the @LessThan100YearsOld annotation so that it can only be applied to attributes and the implementation class is LessThan100YearsOldImpl.

answer.text:
@Target({ ElementType.FIELD})
@Constraint(validatedBy = LessThan100YearsOldImpl.class)
public @interface LessThan100YearsOld {
  String message() default "The date must not be older than 100 years!";
}

public class LessThan100YearsOldImpl implements ConstraintValidator<LessThan100YearsOld, Date> {
  @Override
  public void initialize( LessThan100YearsOld arg0) { ... }
  @Override
  public boolean isValid( Date date, ConstraintValidatorContext context) { ... }
}

@Target({ ElementType.FIELD, ElementType.METHOD})
@Constraint(validatedBy = LessThan100YearsOldImpl.class)
public @interface LessThan100YearsOld {
  String message() default "The date must not be older than 100 years!";
}

public class LessThan100YearsOldImpl implements ConstraintValidator<LessThan100YearsOld, Date> {
  @Override
  public void initialize( LessThan100YearsOld arg0) { ... }
  @Override
  public boolean isValid( Date date, ConstraintValidatorContext context) { ... }
}

feedback.text: The @Target annotation specifies that the custom created @LessThan100YearsOld annotation can also apply to class methods. The requirement was to allow the annotation only for class attributes/fields.

answer.text:
@Target({ ElementType.FIELD})
public @interface LessThan100YearsOld {
  String message() default "The date must not be older than 100 years!";
}

public class LessThan100YearsOldImpl implements ConstraintValidator<LessThan100YearsOld, Date> {
  @Override
  public void initialize( LessThan100YearsOld arg0) { ... }
  @Override
  public boolean isValid( Date date, ConstraintValidatorContext context) { ... }
}

feedback.text: Missing @Constraint(validatedBy = LessThan100YearsOldImpl.class) which specifies the implementation class.

answer.text:
@Target({ ElementType.FIELD})
public @interface LessThan100YearsOld extends LessThan100YearsOldImpl {
  String message() default "The date must not be older than 100 years!";
}

public class LessThan100YearsOldImpl implements ConstraintValidator<LessThan100YearsOld, Date> {
  @Override
  public void initialize( LessThan100YearsOld arg0) { ... }
  @Override
  public boolean isValid( Date date, ConstraintValidatorContext context) { ... }
}

feedback.text: The @LessThan100YearsOld does not specify the required implementation class by using @Constraint(validatedBy = LessThan100YearsOldImpl.class). Also it is syntactically incorrect in Java to have an interface which extends a class.

String fullErrMsg = "A person with the given ID already exists!";

        FacesMessage.SEVERITY_ERROR, shortErrMsg , fullErrMsg));

String shortErrMsg = "Failed to create the person entry.";
String fullErrMsg = "A person with the given ID already exists!";
throw new Exception( shortErrMsg , fullErrMsg);

answer.text:
String shortErrMsg = "Failed to create the person entry.";
String fullErrMsg = "A person with the given ID already exists!";
throw new ValidatorException( shortErrMsg , fullErrMsg);

feedback.text: The be able to display the error message in a JSF message element, the ValidatorException must be created with a FacesMessage instance as parameter.

answer.text:
String shortErrMsg = "Failed to create the person entry.";
String fullErrMsg = "A person with the given ID already exists!";
throw new FacesMessage( FacesMessage.SEVERITY_ERROR, shortErrMsg , fullErrMsg);

feedback.text: The FacesMessage is not an exception, instead it is just a container for the error messages and must be used by an instance of the ValidatorException.

questiontext.text:
Consider the constraints specified by the class diagram on the right.

Which of the following JavaScript code fragments implements these constraints?

answer.text:
if (name === undefined) {
  return "A name is required!";
} else if (typeof( name) !== "string" || name.trim() === "") {
  return "Name must be a non-empty string!";
} else if (age !== undefined) {
  if (!Number.isInteger( age) || age < 0) {
    return "Age must be a non-negative integer!"
  }
} else return "";  // no error

if (name === undefined) {
  return "A name is required!";
} else if (typeof( name) !== "string" || name.trim() === "") {
  return "Name must be a non-empty string!";
} else if (age < 0) {
    return "Age must be a non-negative integer!"
} else return "";  // no error

feedback.text: We cannot test for age < 0, since age may not be provided as it is an optional property.

answer.text:
if (name === undefined) {
  return "A name is required!";
} else if (typeof( name) !== "string") {
  return "Name must be a string!";
} else if (age !== undefined) {
  if (!Number.isInteger( age) || age < 0) {
    return "Age must be a non-negative integer!"
  }
} else return "";  // no error

feedback.text: The value for the property name must not only be a string, but it must also be non-empty.

answer.text:
if (name === undefined) {
  return "A name is required!";
} else if (typeof( name) !== "string" || name.trim() === "") {
  return "Name must be a non-empty string!";
} else if (age === undefined || !Number.isInteger( age) || age < 0) {
    return "Age must be a non-negative integer!"
} else return "";  // no error

    this.isbn = i;

    throw validationResult;
  }
};

Book.prototype.setIsbn = function (i) {
  const validationResult = Book.checkIsbn(i);
  if (validationResult instanceof NoConstraintViolation) {

  }
};

  }
};

questiontext.text:
Consider the OO class model shown on the right-hand side.

Complete the following code of the toJSON method of the Committee class:

toJSON() {
  var rec = {};
  for (const p of Object.keys( this)) {
    if (p.charAt(0) !== "_") continue;
    switch (p) {
    case "_chair":
      // convert object reference to ID reference
      if (this._chair) rec.chair_id = {1:SHORTANSWER_C:~=this._chair.memberId~=this.chair.memberId};
      break;
    default:
      // remove underscore prefix
      rec[p.substr(1)] = this[p];
    }
  }
  return rec;
}
Making the assumption that books existentially depend on their publishers, which of the following Publisher.destroy methods correctly implements the implied deletion dependency?

answer.text:
Publisher.destroy = function (name) {
  const publisher = Publisher.instances[name];
  for (const key of Object.keys( Book.instances)) {
    const book = Book.instances[key];
    if (book.publisher === publisher) {
      delete Book.instances[key];
    }
  }
  delete Publisher.instances[name];
};

Publisher.destroy = function (name) {
  const publisher = Publisher.instances[name];
  for (const key of Object.keys( Book.instances)) {
    const book = Book.instances[key];
    if (book.publisher === publisher) {
      delete book._publisher;
    }
  }
  delete Publisher.instances[name];
};

Publisher.destroy = function (name) {
  const publisher = Publisher.instances[name];
  for (const key of Object.keys( Book.instances)) {
    const book = Book.instances[key];
    if (book.publisher === publisher) {
      book.publisher = undefined;
    }
  }
  delete Publisher.instances[name];
};

An ordered-set-valued property is implemented by representing ordered sets as JS maps.
A bag-valued property is implemented by representing bags (also called 'multi-sets') as JS maps.

questiontext.text:
What is the output of the following program?

function foo() {
  var i=7;
  for (var i=0; i < 10; i++) {
    ...  // do something
  }
  console.log( i);
};
foo();

generalfeedback.text: Since there is no block scope in JS, the value of i at the end of the function execution is 10.

feedback.text: The counter of a for loop is always incremented at the end of a loop cycle before the next loop cycle starts. Only when the value of i is greater than 9, that is when i=10, the loop is terminated.

Each Van has at most one Person as Owner.
Each Person is Owner of at most one Car.

name.text: Check the equality of Java objects

questiontext.text: How can we check, if two Java objects are equal from a logic point of view, not as memory addresses?

answer.text: by implementing the equals method, where we define what exactly means that two objects of a specified type are equal, then we can use obj1.equals(obj2);
we use the == operator, that allows to check the equality of any Java type (primitive or object types);
we use the === operator, that allows to check the equality of any Java type (primitive or object types);
we serialize the objects to string, then we check if the two strings are equal;

Consider the following definition of an enumeration:

const BookCategoryEL = new Enumeration(["novel", "biography", "text book"]);

Recall that

  1. an enumeration literal is a combination of an enumeration name and an enumeration literal name,
  2. an enumeration literal name is formed on the basis of an enumeration literal label, as provided in the Enumeration constructor, and
  3. the value of an enumeration literal is a positive integer, called "enumeration index".

Is it possible to define Java enumerations with the help of enum such that each enumeration literal has a custom label? If yes, briefly explain how.

generalfeedback.text: Yes, it is possible. For example, we can use a label property with range String for the enumeration type, at the definition time. The label value is assigned by a custom constructor method, for each enumeration literal. When the label value is needed somewhere in the code, a getter, i.e., String getLabel(){return this.label;} is used to retrieve it.

Defining a (constant) set of colors, which can be used both, to allow selection in the user interface as well as to store them in a consistent way, by using some sort of data storage, such as a database.

The following literals (but not limited to) may be part of the ColorEL enumeration: RED, BLUE, YELLOW, GREEN, WHITE and BLACK. Since the number of literals is relatively small, and the existing values are unlikely to change over time, this is one example of a case when enumerations make sense.

generalfeedback.text: FetchType.EAGER, implies that a retrieval of an entity, includes a retrieval of the associated entity (or entities) referenced by the entity via the property containing the annotation with this parameter.

Complete the code of the following Person.destroy method such that a "drop reference" deletion policy for the reference property Car::owner : Person is implemented. This reference property implements the unidirectional one-to-many association Person-owns-Car.

public class Person {
  ...
  public static void destroy( EntityManager em, UserTransaction ut, 
      Integer personId) Exception {
    ut.begin();
    Person person = em.find( Person.class, personId);
    Query query = em.createQuery("SELECT c FROM Car c 
	    WHERE c.owner.personId = :personId");
    query.setParameter( "personId", personId);
    List<Car> cars = query.getResultList();
    for ( Car c: cars) { {1:SHORTANSWER_C:=c.setOwner(null)~%100%c.setOwner( null)};}
    em.remove( person);
    ut.commit();
  }
  ...
}

What is the truth value of the Boolean expression true && false || true ?

generalfeedback.text: A disjunction is true if at least one of its disjuncts is true. Since the second disjunct is true, the entire disjunction is true.

questiontext.text:
Recall that the symbol % denotes the arithmetic modulo operation. Evaluate the following Boolean expression:

(8%3 > 1) && !(8%3 > 2)

generalfeedback.text: 8%3 equals 2, and therefore the first conjunct is true, and the second one as well (since 2 is not greater than 2). Since both conjuncts are true, the conjunction is true as well.

questiontext.text:
Evaluate the following Boolean expression:

!undefined
What is the truth value of the Boolean expression null || !0 ?

generalfeedback.text: Since the second disjunct evaluates to true, the disjunction also evaluates to true.

questiontext.text:
Evaluate the following Boolean expression:

!"" && 2=="2"

Evaluate the following Boolean expression:

!"hello!" || 1==="1"

generalfeedback.text: The negation operator ! applied to a non-empty string evaluates to false in JS. Also the second disjunct evaluates to false, since the number 1 is not the same as the digit "1". Consequently, the entire disjunction evaluates to false.

questiontext.text: Define the meaning of @SessionScoped used to annotate managed beans.

generalfeedback.text: @SessionScoped, means that a managed bean is created when the session starts, and destroyed when the session is closed.

name.text: No responsive validation of ID constraints

questiontext.text: Why is the responsive validation of ID constraints (on input) not possible in a JS/Firebase app?

generalfeedback.text: As opposed to the JS/LocalStorage validation app, in the JS/Firebase validation app, ID constraints can no longer be checked on user input, because their check now requires invoking an asynchronous database access operation that may take too much time.

questiontext.text:
What is the purpose of the arrow function as the argument of the map function in the following expression?

(await db.collection("books").get()).docs.map( d => d.data())
Which of the following statements apply to Firestore?

answer.text: Firestore supports certain forms of non-elementary attributes with composite data values (lists, records, record lists).
A Firestore database record is called a document.
A Firestore database table (representing a set of records) is called a collection.

A Firestore collection does not have a schema, implying that any document can be stored in a particular collection. For instance, the document {name:"X", age:13} can be stored in the collection "books".
A Firestore database table (representing a set of records) is called a document.
A Firestore database record is called a collection.

A Firestore collection has a certain schema (i.e., a list of attributes), implying that only documents that comply with its schema (having values for the given attributes) can be stored in a particular collection.

questiontext.text: What kind of JS object is returned by invoking the Firestore function db.collection(x).doc(y).get()?

name.text: Issue of validation with Security Rules

questiontext.text: What is an issue/problem when doing backend validation with Firebase Security Rules?

generalfeedback.text: It would be preferable to reuse the check functions defined in the model code. But the Firebase Security Rules language requires to rewrite these functions, creatinga code duplication issue.

}

questiontext.text: In a Firestore-based project, web developers can use Firebase Security Rules to

answer.text: manage access rights for database tables in conjunction with Firebase Authentication.
validate the incoming data of create and update operations before it is stored in the database.
define which HTTP security headers are required for accessing the Firestore service via HTTP messages.
define which data encryption keys are applied for encrypting sensitive data.
